awd_abstract_narration:
A national shortage of STEM teachers is still a reality.  According to 2016 report from the Center for Public Education, "Fixing the Holes in the Teacher Pipeline: An Overview of Teacher Shortages," STEM teaching vacancies remain the hardest to fill nationwide.  Schools with a high percentage of minority or low-income students find it much more difficult to hire and retain STEM teachers (Center for Public Education, 2016).  The overarching goal of the NSF Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program is to increase the quality, diversity, and number of the nation's STEM teachers who are well prepared to engage students in high-need school districts.  Another critical need is continued engagement of outstanding Noyce teachers to support them in persisting in the teaching profession.  To continue to meet this goal, the Western Regional Noyce Alliance (WRNA) proposes to provide Noyce participants in twelve western states with four tiers of professional growth opportunities.  These opportunities include three annual regional conferences, eighteen regional networking workshops, six mathematical and summer institutes, and research experiences for Noyce Scholars and Fellows.  The states in the western region are California, Washington, Oregon, Nevada, Idaho, Arizona, New Mexico, Colorado, Utah, Texas, Wyoming, and Montana.  

This project intends to support nine institutions to provide the coordinated professional development over three years.  These institutions are San Francisco State University (as the lead), California Polytechnic State University, California State University-Fresno, Northern Arizona University, San Diego State University, the University of Arizona, the University of Portland, the University of Texas at Arlington, the University of Wyoming.  Over the three-year project, WRNA conferences are expected to serve about 950 Noyce participants.  In addition, the project intends to reach 150 Noyce teachers through summer institutes and 1,200 participants through regional networking workshops, and to engage nine additional Noyce participants in immersive summer research.  The WRNA is expected to help increase the number of future STEM leaders in the region's high-need school districts who are well-prepared to effectively implement the Next Generation Science Standards and/or the Common Core State Standards in Mathematics, as more Western Region states fully adopt or include similar standards in their STEM curricula.  Noyce leaders will have more opportunities to gain a better understanding of Noyce evaluation and research efforts both nationally and locally.  Noyce projects that have had years of success will mentor and support newer projects.  This effort may help sustain Noyce influence at each of the western region campuses over time and beyond the lifetime of the award.  Supporting the continued growth of Noyce teachers as outstanding STEM professionals is expected to assist in their persistence as classroom teachers and instructional leaders.  The indirect impact of WRNA is expected to be that hundreds of thousands of students in high-need school districts will receive a high-quality STEM education from teachers who are well-trained in new and exciting directions in STEM education.  Moreover, the findings from the robust project evaluation conducted by the American Institute of Research (AIR), along with an individual educational researcher, has the potential to assist other STEM educators to provide effective professional growth opportunities, in support of retaining outstanding teachers in the teaching profession, particularly in those serving in high-need school districts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Western Regional Noyce Alliance (WRNA) provided multiple professional development and networking opportunities for Noyce Scholars and Principal Investigators associated with the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program across the Western United States. This region included 14 states: Alaska, Arizona, California, Colorado, Hawaii, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Texas, Utah, Washington, and Wyoming. The project hosted three WRN Conferences, with 226 participants attending in Tucson, February 2019, 227 participants in Portland, February 2020, and 265 participants in San Diego, February 2022. Each event ran from Friday through Sunday and featured keynote speakers, PD workshops, breakout groups, and networking opportunities. In total, the project involved participants from over 50 Noyce campuses.

 Additionally, the WRNA provided longer-duration intensive summer PD opportunities over four summers. Over the Grant, multiple two-week workshops were held at CalPoly San Luis Obispo covering Biology, Chemistry and Physics, focused on Modeling Science pedagogy promoted by the American Modeling Teachers Association. Two-week workshops focused on model based math instruction were held at Northern Arizona University. During the Pandemic, all summer workshops were shifted online lead by both Cal Poly Slo and NAU supporting both Math and Science teachers. In total 252 participants attended summer science and math institutes. The project also supported regional Networking Gatherings for in-service Noyce Teachers associated with Professional Teaching conferences in Texas, California, and Wyoming/Northern Colorado. Over the 7 years the grant was active, these Networking gatherings supported over 525 Noyce teachers. The WRNA also supported 25 Noyce Scholars to participate in eight-week paid summer research opportunities at national labs and research facilities to develop identity as teacher-researchers as part of their Noyce preparation. These were sponsored by the STEM Teacher and Research (STAR) program headquartered at CalPoly Slo. All professional development opportunities included intentional emphasis on Common Core State Standards (CCSS) and Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS).

 Collaborating with the American Institutes for Research (AIR), the WRNA leadership team undertook research investigating the impact of WRNA supported professional development on 29 participating Noyce teachers’ implementation of scientific or mathematical modeling. The researchers were required to pivot during the COVID-19 pandemic from collecting all video evidence for analysis to collecting video, when possible, along with lesson plans and virtual observations for analysis. AIR found changes in teacher practices after WRNA PD and the implementation of modeling in a virtual classroom. Although the ratings of most lesson plans across criteria did not change, it is promising that the researchers found almost half of the science teachers had increased alignment to “eliciting student ideas” fundamental to a modeling approach. It was also positive to find in submitted videos (a) most videos included student-directed elements of modeling and (b) teachers were providing opportunities for modeling.

Intellectual Merit

The intellectual merit associated with all Noyce activities included professional experiences supporting teachers who work in high need settings, learning new teaching strategies and upgrading content knowledge through annual two-day conferences, summer Institutes and Regional Networking gatherings. These activities exposed Noyce participants to resources and PD training in methods employing proven practices in teacher preparation and induction. Participants were able to collaborate and share experiences, expertise, and skills with their peers and colleagues through presentations, concurrent sessions, person-to-person interactions, and follow-up online networking. Overall, these activities built a network of Noyce Scholars who were better prepared to teach high needs students, who were equipped to adapt instruction to students with different needs, and who had confidence to implement new lessons and teaching strategies. Additionally, the conferences resulted in a network of Noyce leadership with increased confidence to implement new strategies in their programs, work together to improve local experiences for all Noyce Scholars and assess and publish findings related to the Noyce program and experiences.

 Broader Impacts

 The WRNA impacted nearly 1,500 aspiring and early-career STEM educators committed to teaching in high need school districts across the Western Region. These participants gained new knowledge on effective STEM teaching, gained more in-depth knowledge of effective student engagement strategies aligned with new science and common core standards, learned about outstanding online resources and learning communities that will help them to achieve at the highest level in the classroom, and interacted with colleagues across a wide region of the United States electronically. The project helped increase the number of future STEM leaders prepared to effectively implement the Next Generation Science Standards and/or Common Core State Standards. Noyce leaders developed better understandings of Noyce program evaluation efforts both nationally and locally. Research findings were shared and newer and veteran Noyce leaders interacted to benefit their Noyce programs. This impact helped sustain Noyce's influence at each campus over time and well beyond the lifetime of the award. With support provided by the WRNA, over 150,000 pre-college students annually will receive a STEM education from teachers who are well trained in STEM teaching and learning.


 


 

 


Last Modified: 04/14/2025
Modified by: Larry Horvath
